resources.string: Fortunately, more female candidates can help counteract the paradox — basically by increasing voters’ exposure to several different female voices and allowing people to envision one of those faces being president. Seeing so many competent women on the campaign trail may trigger what psychologists call the “contact hypothesis,” the theory that the more a person is exposed to someone from their social “out-group,” the more sympathetic that person becomes to all members of the out-group. We also know that in today’s polarized climate, people tend to see their co-partisans as their “in-group,” and opposite partisans as their “out-group.” By having more viable women in the presidential race, voters are making “contact” with a variety of female candidates, each of whom is currently courting a different part of the Democratic constituency (Warren, the inequality wonk; Harris, the general progressive; Klobuchar, the pragmatist; Gillibrand,
